title: What is the importance of speaking skills? - Quora

response.answer_text: A simple conversation can end up in love. A love that could last forever. Only through communication the world exists, and human life can hold meaning. Communication helps to understand the information accurately and quickly. Being able to communicate our, thoughts, opinions, and wishes has always been important for our survival. A lot of loneliness in the world is because of the lack of communication—Between a boy friend and girlfriend, between husband and a wife, between parents and children, between friends, between families. There might be a lot of people around you and you can still feel LONELY, because of the lack of communication or unable to communicate about the things that seem important to you. Honest , raw real communication is beautiful. It’s pure. It changes everything. Get it out. Unburden yourself. Say what you feel respectfully. Help others understand whatever is going on. No one can read your mind. A lack of communication breeds assumptions. Don’t let them assume what you are thinking or feeling. That’s when misunderstandings happen and relationships break. Most of the times assumptions are incorrect. You and I when we can not communicate our feelings. Tell me what could go wrong? You certainly can’t expect what you didn’t communicate. Good communication helps to strengthen and builds honest and healthy friendships and relationships. Here it is .. If I did something wrong, come and tell me, communicate. Have I not listened to you well enough ? Break it down, Tell me again in a way that I can understand. If I hurt your feelings, I’m sorry— but make me aware of it. Let me know so that I don’t repeat it. If I am insensitive to your needs, to your desires or to your thoughts- communicate so that I can consider. But if you do not communicate then don’t expect me to behave a certain way. Tell me why you are sad, Tell me why you are angry with me, Tell me how I can fix it , Talk. Communicate clearly. Because after all I don’t know what’s going on. Before you raise a wall of defense , Before you speak in anger, hurt and fear, before you break off with me— Tell me, did I really hear everything that you have to say? Don’t argue, but Discuss with me—we are not here to prove who is right but what is right. So, Some pointers on how to communicate well—listen, observe, speak concisely, observe, analyse, Be open minded. Communicate humbly and respectfully. Use appropriate medium of communication depending on the situations. Don’t break up over a text. Its kinder way to call and tell. Emails are great way to communicate at work place and businesses. Communication is an art that connects people’s lives together. When you LISTEN to your partner’s feelings with out getting angry and frustrated you will be able to allow them to feel safe and express their feelings. The more he or she feels understood, the more they will be able to give you- their loving trust, acceptance, appreciation, admiration, approval and encouragement that he/ she needs. Communicate, even when it’s uncomfortable or uneasy. That’s how you heal when you let it all out. When you open up and communicate, life becomes simpler and it’s easier. Don’t wait to tell someone that you miss them, call them now. Invite people for a coffee when you want to catch up with them. If you think someone has misunderstood you, explain to them. Help them understand. Miscommunication is the root of every problem, pause- Think about all the times you didn’t say things you wanted to and how the other person misunderstood you. Remember every word has consequences, and every silence too. So if you don’t say it then don’t expect to be understood. At work or in relationships— ask questions. Don’t wait for someone to come give you the answers. If you want to know something just ask. When you have to compliment someone or appreciate someone— say it. The worst distance between two people is misunderstanding. A simple sorry could have save a relationship. Put the pride away and communicate. Let them know you are sorry. If someone is being annoying and you don’t like it— speak to them gently, politely. Tell them how you feel. If you love someone — let them know! ♥️

The art of effective communication takes time to hone. That said, it’s not optional as communication represents the expression of your ideas, hopes and desires. It also represents how you advocate for change or persuade others to act. No matter your job, you probably have to communicate with a boss, manager and colleagues using email, instant messaging and in team meetings. And you will have to persuade somebody to hire you, promote you, date you, or listen to you at some point. I know my strengths and weaknesses. Years ago, I used to have a stutter but I fixed that through speech and drama. These days, I find verbal communication more challenging than written communication. Unlike many people, I find it easier to listen than to interject and push my opinions across. I ask a lot of of questions and sometimes this can feel like an interrogation. On the other hand, some people find it all but impossible to listen to another person without interruption or trying to fix what that person is going to say. Whatever your strengths, weakness or communication style, it’s relatively easy to improve your communication skills. You could, for example, join Toastmasters and get better at speaking in public. Or you could start journaling and improve your written communication skills. Using speech to text software can help too. It also helps to learn the basics of active listening whereby you focus on and reflect on what a person says rather than try to fix their problems or explain what’s on your mind. Starting a podcast is a good way of improving your skills too as it will force you to listen to another person and eliminate verbal ticks like saying “um” or “eh” a lot. Trump, whatever you think of his politics, has boiled down the art of communication to short soundbites that sound good on Twitter or in a news clip even if they don’t make a lot of sense when you listen to to the entire speech.
